0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Tuberculosis; Diagnosis: Mantoux test, inject 0.1 mL (5 tuberculin units) INTRADERMALLY; the result is read 48 to 72 hr after administration

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Tuberculosis; Diagnosis: Mantoux test, inject 0.1 mL (5 tuberculin units) INTRADERMALLY; the result is read 48 to 72 hr after administration

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• allergy to tuberculin or any component of the product or prior allergic or severe reaction (eg, anaphylactic shock, blistering, ulceration, or necrosis) to tuberculin purified protein derivative test
  • burns, extensive
  • eczema, extensive
  • TB, active or history of treatment

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions may occur; emergency treatment must be immediately available
  • concomitant corticosteroids, immunosuppressive agents, or certain live vaccines; may depress or suppress reactivity to tuberculin testing
  • concomitant parenteral live attenuated virus vaccines; delay tuberculin testing for at least one month
  • mycobacteria infection, including BCG vaccination; increased risk of false-positive reaction
  • syncope may occur with administration; avoid falling hazards and have acute treatment available
  • test interpretation errors, including false-negative and false-positive test reactions, may occur

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Syncope
  • Dermatologic:Injection site disorder, Vesiculation, Necrosis, Skin ulcer
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Parenteral-Local: Intradermally injected tuberculin PPD causes a delayed (cellular) hypersensitivity reaction in individuals sensitized by mycobacterial infection. Following infection with mycobacteria, sensitization of T-cells occurs primarily in the regional lymph nodes. Natural infection with M. tuberculosis usually initiates a cell-mediated immune response against mycobacterial antigens. T-cells proliferate in response to the infection and give rise to T-cells specifically sensitized to mycobacterial antigens. After several weeks, these T-lymphocytes enter the bloodstream and circulate for a long period of time. Subsequent restimulation of these T-lymphocytes with intradermal injection of tuberculin PPD evokes a local reaction mediated by these cells.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    intradermal is the preferred route; do not give IV, IM, or subQ
  • Intradermal
    • do not dilute solution
    • inject intradermally, using a tuberculin syringe with a 26 or 27 gauge needle, into the epidermal (most superficial) layers of the skin on the flexor (volar) surface of the forearm
    • insert needle with bevel pointing upward; a 6 mm to 10 mm pale bleb will rise at the needle point and disappear within minutes; if a bleb does not form, immediately repeat the injection at least 2 inches from the original injection site
    • no dressing is required

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• skin reaction; interpret 48 to 72 hours after injection: results based only on palpable induration measured in mm transversely to the long axis
  • skin reaction; a positive hypersensitivity reaction to the tuberculin skin test may not be seen until 2 to 10 weeks after the infection
  • induration of 5 mm or greater is positive in recently-exposed individuals, persons with HIV infection or risk factors for HIV, organ transplant patients, and persons with a fibrotic chest x-ray consistent with healed TB
  • induration of 10 mm or greater is positive in all persons who belong to a high-risk or high-prevalance group for TB
  • induration of 15 mm or greater is positive in persons without any risk factors
  • HIV-infected patients who test negative and belong to high-risk populations; perform annual repeated testing
  • health-care workers: two-step method is recommended at the time of initial testing; if the first test result is negative, the second step of the two-step baseline testing should be repeated in 1 to 3 wk; if the second test result is positive, consider patient has latent TB infection, if the second result is negative, the health care worker is classified as uninfected; recent conversion in health care workers is defined as a positive hypersensitivity reaction greater than or equal to 10 mm increase within a 2 yr period or an increase of a 15 mm within a 2 yr (if facility unlikely to have TB exposure).

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Instruct patient to visit healthcare professional 48 to 72 h after injection for interpretation of skin reaction.
